title: Thursday, 16th May 2019
byline: Jamie Powell, Thomas Hale, Izabella Kaminska

nightingale20201 morning all
11:10 am
JP11:10am

WeWork’s office culture remains a huge part of what the co-working company is selling. Its mission statement is to “elevate the world’s consciousness.” Co-founders wearing shirts that read “High on We” and “Operationalize Love” address workers sipping from metal, reusable cups that read “Always Half Full.” At least five executives, most of them regional managers, have the title chief We officer (CWeO). WeWork has flown tens of thousands of employees and members to twice-annual bacchanals in Los Angeles and the English countryside, and it also buys carbon offsets and removed meat from its offices last summer. (Employees can’t expense meat anymore, either. The company says it’s ending one of those big parties, called Summer Camp.) These kinds of elements, like the beers, make up the story WeWork wants to tell, and that story is the CEO’s.

JP11:10am

Totally early cycle stuff.

Forester Thomas Cook.....must be getting old, I thought it was still part of Midland Bank!
JP11:11am

Anyway, apparently WeWork is creating a fund to buy buildings, to go along with its leasing obligations.

JP11:13am

Tesla is updating the software in its electric vehicles following two recent incidents in Asia in which parked cars caught fire. 

The California-based carmaker said on Thursday morning that it would begin rolling out new software immediately that revises “charge and thermal management settings” on all of its Model S and Model X vehicles globally. Tesla said the update will also “further protect the battery and improve battery longevity”.

In late April, a video circulated on Chinese social media showed plumes of smoke billowing from beneath a white Tesla parked in an underground parking garage in Shanghai. The car then erupted into flames and continued to burn for several seconds before the footage stopped.

AMALtd Morning

Bryan this morning on the cover of the spanish newspaper appears this news about norweigan http://www.expansion.com/empresas/transporte/2019/05/16/5cdc6927268e3e23418b45b8.html
Excel Developer #Tesla Hans Werner Sinn says electric cars save no carbon bonce you realised the costs of mining rare earth minerals and charging from non renwewables. We should only subsidise electric motorcycles which have less mass.

Because what has seemingly happened is that McKinsey has decided that the future will look like x, and now x is being propagated in a cult like way across the entire corporate sector. The vision is feedback from the new spate of mystic digital consultants that go into all boardrooms with big childlike posters talking about sandboxes and themeparks.

Excel Developer *once*

Anyway it's really sinister

Forester @BC good its like our new "2 beer rule" . I have plans to bring out a range of ales with names like "Ham Salad" and "Mung Beans"

So there's a homogenisation of vision across the C-suite level?

there's no independent ideas anywhere. Everyone in a trance like way repeats that the future is about ecosystems, connected cars, shared mobility and OEM that are only junior partners to digital behemoths

BornCynic @Shinshin - not in Pfizer. Management did not want a cap on what they could expense and so it had to apply to all employees. Anyone who ate out always had the most expensive items on the menu. The expenses section would therefore not bother looking at receipts - why bother? The only thing they might pick up was a $1,000 bottle of wine.

It wasn't until a dockless bike ended up being lobbed onto a DLR track that the mayor's office was able to convince the wider authority they should have a mandate to curtail this stuff).

11:32 am
JP11:32am

Here's UBS:

JP11:32am

How did results compare vs. expectations?
Thomas Cook reported Q2 Underlying EBIT loss of £185m (UBSe -£167m, 2Q18 a loss £127m). The company booked a £1.1bn goodwill impairment (A closer look at tour operator accounting). Ex impairment, H1 separately disclosed items came in at £37m (1H18 £67m). 1H19 net debt came in at £1,247m (1H18 £886m) driven by a higher 1H working capital cash outflow £529m (vs. 1H18 £392m) and FCF cash outflow of £839m (vs. 1H18 £718m). TC announced it received multiple bids for the airline which it is now assessing. The company also agreed the term sheet for a new bank facility of £300m that should support liquidity for the Winter 2019/20.

JP11:32am

What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
H1 Tour operator EBIT loss came in at £157m (vs. UBSe loss £134m, 1H18 loss £85m) with declining profitability in the Nordics and Continental Europe. The Airline EBIT loss came in at £71m (vs. UBSe -£68m 1H18 -£59m) while corporate costs came in at -£17m (vs UBSe -£25m). Summer 2019 programme is 57% sold (in line with last year) with tour op bookings down 12% (vs. down 12% at 1Q) and pricing up 2% (vs. up 4% at 1Q).

11:32 am
JP11:32am

Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
Yes the guidance has been revised downwards due to challenging market environment. The company now expects 2H underlying EBIT to be down y/y. In 2018 TC generated underlying EBIT of £250m. At 1H underlying EBIT was already £76m down y/y. We forecast 2019 EBIT Underlying of £257m (Reuters consensus £267m).

JP11:32am

Valuation: trades on 13% UBSe 2020e FCF yield
Our 27p PT is derived using an average of i) DCF yielding a FV of 34p/sh; EV/EBITDA yielding a FV of 19p/sh.

Excel Developer @IK, VV75: I actually wasn't talking about shared/hired motorised bicycles but actually like one of these https://www.bloomberg.com/amp/news/articles/2019-05-07/2019-zero-s-electric-motorcycle-review Anyway, let's turn to markets please.

TH11:34am

Thomas Cook has reported an increased seasonal loss of £(245)m, cf £(170)m at the prior interims, on revenue up 4%. The profit decline reflects “margin pressure in the Tour Operator”. In contrast On the Beach reported H1 2019 revenue up 1% in its core business and EBITDA up 10% despite increased investment in central costs. In the UK specifically the H1 2019 EBIT loss increased to £(103)m cf £(23)m in H1 2018. This was despite increased revenue and “good demand for Turkish and Egyptian destinations”. On the Beach has also experienced this destination mix shift, without the negative impact on overall margin. On the Beach’s relationships with hotels are less mature in these destination markets and so there is margin upside potential for OTB as its volumes increase further.

11:34 am
TH11:35am

that's Peel Hunt

JP11:35am

Interesting, seems another example of small specialist businesses eroding aggregators in bad markets.

TH11:35am

and some hints of spillover effects with supply chain

11:35 am
TH11:35am

Multiples bids “have been received for all and part of the Group Airline”. Thomas Cook’s airline is a key supplier of seats to the holiday market and it is clearly in On the Beach’s interest that it continues to operate on leisure routes without disruption. The sale of the airline does not guarantee this but it is clearly preferable to the airline’s financial failure and restructuring.

JP11:35am

CPG companies being the prime example of where this is playing out.

JP11:36am

Exactly, take one part of the value chain and get really good at it, rather than trying to integrate the entire thing.

Izabella Kaminska @VV75 exactly. They're a nightmare. There have been loads of complaints. The TFL guy showed me the photo of the bike on the DLR track. Unless it's associated with a repressive social credit system, the incentive to vandalise these things will always be there. I've never felt inclined to vandalise anything in my life, but these bikes are tempting me.

here's Jefferies

TH11:42am

Nestle (NESN) have announced that they have entered into exclusive discussions with a consortium including EQT (a private equity firm) and a subsidiary of ADIA (a sovereign wealth fund) for the sale of their Skin Health business for CHF 10.2bn.Skin Health sales in 2018 were CHF 2.8bn and we think EBITDA is between CHF 400m & 500m. So the exit multiple is 3.6x sales & 20-26x EBITDA. We see this as good. For reference, L'Oreal trades on prospective EV:sales of 4x and Unilever have been paying 3-7x sales for a sequence of transactions in the prestige skincare space. However, we note that the Galderma consolidation in 2014 was executed at only 1.5x sales and that our original speculation on the value of Skin Health in September 2018 was CHF 4bn.NESN will update on use of proceeds in H2 but we expect this news to fuel expectations of further buyback activity. Given media reports on the transaction value impacted the market yesterday, we expect a modest positive reaction this morning.

Excel Developer @red: I am puzzled, I know there is the canonical inverse correlation between stocks and bonds but the trade threats if materialised would represent a negative supply shock which would cut growth but also be inflationary. So why have nominal bonds rallied? I can understand inflation protected securities rallying (TIPS). The only reason I think explains is that the Fed is stopping the roll off of securities bought with QE, that means price support for bonds and lower yields.

11:48 am
JP11:49am

In case you were wondering about the adjustments:

JP11:49am

Adjusting items*

Adjusting items amounted to a £2m charge (2018: £59m charge) with £1m adjusting operating items and £1m adjusting finance items.

The most significant item was restructuring costs of £12m. This was partly offset by a £7m income relating to the reversal of provisions taken in relation to the disposal of the beauty business and £4m income relating to revaluation of Burberry Middle East deferred consideration.

* For detail on adjusting items see Appendix and notes 7 and 8 of the Financial Statements

After taking account of adjusting items, reported profit before tax increased by 7% to £441m.

JP11:49am

Deferred consideration revaluation. Interesting.

11:49 am

JP11:50am

Anyway, here's UBS:

JP11:50am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: H2 19 revenue of £1,500m is a touch lower than UBSe (£1,501), with adjusted EBIT of £260m at 1% lower than UBSe £262m (cons £264m). Q4 LFL 1% (UBSe +1%).

Soundbuy Burberry - chequered past?
11:50 am
JP11:50am

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Retail Q4 grew +1% on constant FX (UBSe +3%), with +1% LFL, underlying space -1.6% and a +1.6% positive impact from retail calendar and IFRS 15. Tisci collection up DD. Wholesale was higher at +4% in H2 (UBSe +1%). H2 gross margin down -70bp (UBSe -90bp), opex savings £41m (ahead of £35m planned), but offset by £4m higher FX headwind and opex inflation, leading to EBIT margin of 17.3% (UBSe 17.1%).

JP11:50am

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: FY20 guidance unchanged with flat EBIT at c.c., although -7m FX headwind meaning £431m (UBSe £439m, cons £448m). Additional £15m cost savings by FY22.

JP11:50am

Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: We expect the £150m share buyback (1.8% of market cap) to mitigate the underlying EBIT miss; focus will likely be on Tisci's collection sell-out at conference call.

JP12:00pm

Whilst it may be of secondary importance to its capital position, Q1 sales at Just highlighted that it is taking a disciplined approach towardscapital. It has reported Retirement income sales in Q1 at £184m (-59%) driven primarily by DB de-risking sales down 90%and GIfL sales at £145m (-23%). DB sales are lumpy and so far in Q2 sales have recovered to £300m+ whilst the slowdown in GIfL sales is in line with previous guidance. Plans are in place to ensure the capital position remains robust and in line with our forecasts.We welcome the disciplined approach to capital management andbelieve that during the next 12 months Just will demonstrate that it can achieve capital neutral target by 2022. We consequently maintain our Buy recommendation and 130p target price.

12:00 pm
JP12:01pm

Q1 Sales-Total Retirement income sales of £196m(-58%) were driven by a big reduction in DB de-risking volumes at £26m (-90%). DB salesare lumpy in nature and consequently hard to forecast but on a positive note Just comments that the reduction was due to a temporary reduction in activity levels. Reinforcing this it commented that so far in Q2 it has completed DB transactions with a value more than £300m, the pipeline remains full and margins are attractive. Further, it confirmed earlier guidance that DB sales for 2019 will be similar to the annualised H2 2018 rate.GIfL salesreduced 23% to £145m reflecting disciplined pricingincreases following the PRA’s CP13/18 last year and are in line with previous guidance of a run rate more akin to that achieved in Q4 2018. Lifetime mortgage advancesat £79m (-47%) were down reflecting the reduction in retirement sales and a focus on capital efficientLTMs

GBKrona @Red - shame that majority of the rest of Labour are Remainers. Also a shame that Corbyn is not a democrat...
red @marktimeif youre invested elsewhere you can invest in and around very cheaply as i suspect he would be out on his ear after one term.
JP12:01pm

Outlook–Just has commented that its GIfL and DB pricing standards have been implemented rigorously to ensure that it can deliver new business IRRs at the mid-teenslevel for shareholders. The capital position has improved following the £375m raised in March and the focus is on achieving capital neutrality by 2022. Just says that it has a plan in place over the course of 2019 to achieve that target. It includes actions such as a renewed focus on costs, closure of loss-makingbusinesses (e.g. the USoperation), a reduction in new business LTM backing ratios and a move towards more capital efficient assets.

JP12:02pm

Investment view–Whilst we had not anticipated the lack of DB sales in Q1 we welcome the Q2 recovery along with the disciplined approach to new business and capital management. Given recent events we can understand why some investors are sceptical of the capital position but in recent larger notes we identified its capital ratio falling to what we believe to be an adequate level in 2022 before recovering thereafter.We think that current valuation is very attractive in isolation but anticipate that Just will be acquired by a larger, more diversified competitorin the medium term. We maintain our 130p target price and Buy recommendation.

JP12:06pm

At a headline level, Hargreaves reported numbers which beat across the board.
However, when delving into the detail it is apparent that organic growth and
revenue margins are worse for several reasons:
1) Closing AUMA of £97.8bn is ~3% ahead of consensus, however revenuesare
in-linethus margins weak. This implies weaker fee rates/margins and can be
explained by lower stockbroking revenues being more than offset by higher net
interest income (both of which is in-line with our expectations),however the
margin on the funds business i.e. platform/distribution fees and other income is
lower owing to mix - for example active savings is low single digit bps we believe.

BornCynic Thanks IK / JP / TH / ROTR
12:06 pm
JP12:06pm

2) Net new business of £2.9bn is ~20% below consensusafteradjustingfor low
margin and one-offs. Headline flows are in-line to slightly better than consensus
expectations of £2.8bn,however the flow number includes £399m of Active
savings inflows (low to no revenue margin),£267m transfer in business from
Witan. Adjusting for these two factors implies organic growth of £2.23bn a ~20%
miss vs. consensus and down ~32% YoY.Furthermore, the flow in the period was
boosted by some portion of ~£200m linked to the launch of the HL Select
Global Growth fund but as we do not know the amount we do not adjust for
this thus the organicnumber is worse than our calculations above.

Soundbuy HL.
JP12:06pm

3) Net new clientadds of53k is ~18% below consensusafteradjustingfor

transfers. In the four months ending April,netnew client adds of 53k is prime-
facie ~2% ahead of consensus. Though this number includes 10-11k of Witan

clients transferred in. Adjusting for (the mid-point) of this would imply new client
numbers are down ~30% YoY and are ~18% below consensus expectations.
In all, lookingforward we do notexpect consensusearnings to change on the
back of this - however the mix we do expect to changei.e. organicgrowth lower
and one-offs to be higheras further JPM and Baillie Gifford transfers will occur
through thecourse of2019/2020.
